Children's books for holiday giving

A look at seasonal books, picture books and chapter books for the kids on your gift list

Children's books for holiday giving

Carla Carlton, Special to The Courier-Journal 11:42 a.m. EST December 12, 2014

“Here Comes Santa Cat”(Photo: Provided)

1 CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

With the internet's seemingly infinite inventory and the ease of one-click ordering, it's possible to do all of your holiday shopping these days without ever stepping foot in an actual store.

While I enjoy making purchases in my pajamas as much as the next person, I think it's a mistake to shop for children's books that way. Want the latest Stephen King or Sue Grafton? Amazon away. You know what to expect. But if you're buying a picture book for a favorite child, you will want to "read-test" it first, because trust me: You will be reading that book over, and over, and over.

You can do that in the children's section of any of Louisville's bookstores — or you can head to the city's only bookstore just for children. Open since August, Carmichael's Kids in the Highlands, 1313 Bardstown Road, is a cozy space filled with books and related toys and something you don't always find on the internet — expert advice. During my recent visit, the staff guided a grandmother who was looking for the perfect book for a 2-year-old; helped another woman find a Corduroy gift set; and chatted with a cute little girl with glasses who was window-shopping with her mom.

RELATED: Author stresses early reading at library event

They also added some great recommendations to my list. Thanks to Rebecca, Cassie and Corin, and especially to store manager Kelly, who pulled out the tiny table and chair she had just stowed away for the holidays so I'd have a place to sit and read.

SEASONAL BOOKS

The Animals' Santa by Jan Brett (ages 3-5, 32 pp., Putnam Juvenile, $17.99). When my children were small, we read Jan Brett's wonderfully illustrated The Mitten so many times that it fell apart. In this new tale, Big Snowshoe the rabbit regales his brother, Little Snow, with stories of the animals' Santa. But Little Snow thinks he's being tricked, because no one has ever seen this Santa … until this year. The book is filled with Brett's incredibly detailed drawings of woodland creatures, including small side panels on each page that add another layer of interest. (According to her biography, Brett has a pet hedgehog. Of course she does.)

    Here Comes Santa Cat by Deborah Underwood (ages 3-5, 88 pp., Dial, $16.99). It's Dec. 24, and Cat is dressed up as Santa. Why? He fears he's been too naughty to receive presents any other way. Assured by the narrator that it's not too late, he tries to be good, but it all goes wrong: His carols come out as yowls, and no children want his gifts (of fresh fish). But in the end, he is redeemed by a simple act of sharing.

    Skippyjon Jones: Snow What by Judy Schachner (ages 3-5, 32 pp., Dial, $17.99). Perennial favorite Skippyjon Jones, the Siamese cat who thinks he's a Chihuahua, returns in another rollicking, rhyming story. Bored by his sisters' request that their mother read "Snow White," Skippyjon enters his closet and emerges to meet The Seven Chimichangos, who need his help in awakening their princess with a kiss. Yuck! Kids will enjoy watching him squirm — and they'll learn a little Spanish, too.

    PICTURE BOOKS

    Before After by Matthias Arégui and Anne-Margot Ramstein (ages 2 and up, 176 pp., Candlewick Press, $19.99). This popular book of clean, elegant illustrations is simple enough for the youngest non-reader to follow (before: caterpillar; after: butterfly), but clever enough to engage older children as well (before: slingshot; after, broken window). Carmichael's Kids has reordered this title several times.

    Tap to Play! by Salina Yoon (ages 3 and up, 40 pp., Balzer + Bray, $15.99) In 2011, I recommended Hervé Tullet's Press Here (Chronicle, $15.99), in which the reader keeps the story going by pressing, tapping and turning the pages. Now comes Salina Yoon's clever take on the idea. Blip, the circular red fellow who serves as the protagonist, needs to reach a bar at the top of the page to win a prize, and he can't get there without your help. The instructions and their results (Tap twice — wait, not that hard! Splat!) will have kids giggling at their own power.

    Marlene, Marlene, Queen of Mean by Jane Lynch and Lara Embry (ages 3-7, 32 pp., Random House Books for Young Readers, $16.99). Who would know more about being mean than Jane Lynch, the devious Sue Sylvester of television's "Glee"? In her first children's book, she and clinical psychologist Lara Embry tell a rhyming story "of a girl seeking glory" through bullying, and how she's undone — and reformed — when a brave kid named Freddy calls her bluff.

    My Pet Book by Bob Staake (ages 3-7, 40 pp., Random House Books for Young Readers, $17.99). "He never cared for puppy dogs, and kittens made him sneezy. He pleaded with his mom and dad, 'I want a pet that's easy!' " That's how a boy from Smartytown ends up with a small red hardcover on a leash. It can't do tricks, but inside, it holds amazing tales "of awesomeness and glory." Then one day, the maid accidentally gives the book to charity, and a desperate search begins. Kids will giggle at Bob Staake's illustrations (parents may recognize his style from The New York Times), and while they probably won't ever consider their favorite book a pet, they may well agree with the boy's declaration that "every book's a friend."

    Circle, Square, Moose by Kelly Bingham (ages 4-8, 48 pp., Greenwillow Books, $17.99). This book starts out like any old book about shapes (a button is a circle, a sandwich is a square), until it is invaded by an attention-seeking Moose, who begins by chomping into the sandwich ("Hey! Don't eat that!"). The narrator ineffectively pleads for order ("Look, this is a book about shapes. Not animals. You are in the wrong book.") until Zebra, dressed as a referee, arrives to help. A funny story that still manages to teach a few things.

    While You Were Napping by Jenny Offill (ages 4-8, 40 pp., Schwartz & Wade, $16.99). This funny book touches on two universal childhood experiences: the absolute certainty that cool stuff is happening without you when you're asleep, and the compulsion to torture a younger sibling. No, the older sister tells her little brother, you didn't miss anything during your nap. Well, unless you count that giant party, or the construction workers who let us use their bulldozers, or the dinosaur skeleton we dug up, or the robots, or the pirates … Since the book never lets on that all of this fun was fictional, it will be best enjoyed by that older sibling.

    The Book with No Pictures by B.J. Novak (ages 5-8, 48 pp., Dial, $17.99). There really are absolutely no pictures in this book by director, producer and actor B.J. Novak ("The Office"). That may sound boring and serious, it begins, "except … here is how books work: Everything the words say, the person reading the book HAS TO SAY." Even if the words are "Blork," or "Bluurf," or "I am a monkey who taught myself to read." Creative typography and color break up the visuals, and the words are sure to break up your listener, especially when you have to read, "My only friend in the whole wide world is a hippo named BOO BOO BUTT."

    Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel, 75th Anniversary by Virginia Lee Burton (ages 4-8, 56 pp., Clarion Books, $17.99). The edition is new, but the sweet story of Mike Mulligan and his hardworking companion, Mary Anne, remains the same. As gasoline, diesel and electricity replace steam, Mike and Mary Anne seem destined for obsolescence. Then Mike discovers that Popperville, a small town in the country, needs a new City Hall. To prove their worthiness, Mike bets their wages that Mary Anne can dig the entire cellar in a day — but they neglect to leave a way out. The solution to the problem shows that not everything old must be cast aside in the name of progress.

    Ivan: The Remarkable True Story of the Shopping Mall Gorilla by Katherine Applegate (ages 4-8, 40 pp., Clarion Books, $17.99). In 2012, Ivan, a silverback gorilla stolen as a baby from the Congo by poachers, died at the age of 50 in Zoo Atlanta. This is the story of his first 30 years of life: three with a human family, and 27 years alone in a tiny cage at a Tacoma, Wash., shopping mall. Petitions and other public pressure lead to Ivan's relocation to the zoo, where he learns to live with other gorillas and becomes a beloved celebrity. A section in the back includes more facts and photos and a touching tribute by his longtime keeper, Jodi Carrigan, who writes that "his life has been a symbol of the way animals shape our lives … and the power we have to shape theirs."

    Animalium (Welcome to the Museum) by Jenny Broom, art by Katie Scott (all ages, 112 pp., Big Picture Press, $35). Corin at Carmichael's pointed out this gorgeously illustrated, oversized volume about the animal kingdom — invertebrates, fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals. "This museum is like none you've ever visited before," it begins. "It is open twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, and its collection boasts a fascinating catalog of the world's creatures, with each exhibit in immaculate condition and presented in fantastic detail." In addition to the pen-and-ink plates of each specimen, there is a detailed Tree of Animal Life that shows how we are all connected.

    CHAPTER BOOKS

    In addition to being good reads, these five books have something in common: They are all about young people taking personal risks to save someone or something else — up to and including the entire world.

    FICTION

    Ophelia and the Marvelous Boy by Karen Foxlee (ages 8-12, 240 pp., Knopf Books for Young Readers, $16.99). This novel, a retelling of Hans Christian Andersen's "The Snow Queen," had me from the first chapter title: "In which Ophelia Jane Worthington-Whittard discovers a boy in a locked room and is consequently asked to save the world." Ophelia and her older sister Alice, whose mother has recently died, have accompanied their father to a city where it always snows so that he can help to prepare an exhibition of swords in a rather odd museum. Her first day there, Ophelia discovers a locked room containing a Boy who claims to have waited hundreds of years for her to release him and to help find the magical sword that will save the world from the Snow Queen. Ophelia, who is a very logical child, does not believe in magic or Snow Queens but reluctantly agrees to help. Her search for the keys that will unlock the room takes her to dark parts of the museum where she encounters frightening "misery birds" and the ghosts of little girls whose life force has kept the Snow Queen young. Meanwhile, Alice seems to be getting pretty cozy with Miss Kaminski, the chilly museum curator. With echoes of "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" and "Night at the Museum," this story of bravery and belief will keep readers eagerly turning pages until the thrilling conclusion.

    As the second book in James Dashner's Mortality Doctrine series, The Rule of Thoughts (12 and up, 336 pp., Delacorte Press, $18.99), opens, our hero, gamer extraordinaire Michael, awakens to find that he is quite literally not himself. At the end of the first book, The Eye of Minds, he discovered that everything he thought about his life was a lie. But the truth puts him in a unique position to pursue cyber-terrorist Kaine — a computer program that has become sentient — through the VirtNet. Kaine's plan, the Mortality Doctrine, is to place more such programs, known as Tangents, into human bodies. It's up to Michael and his two best friends — gamers he's never met in real life — to stop it.

    Skink: No Surrender by Carl Hiaasen (12 and up, 288 pp., Knopf Books for Young Readers, $18.99). Florida newspaper columnist and author Hiaasen has written several books for younger readers (including Hoot, which was made into a movie). This is his first to feature Skink, aka Clinton Tyree, the one-eyed former governor of Florida who has appeared in several of his adult novels. Richard, our protagonist, encounters Skink on the beach, where he is lying in wait for turtle poachers, and enlists his help in finding his cousin Malley, who has disappeared with a guy she met online. Following clues Malley drops in phone conversations, Richard and Skink track her and her kidnapper to the Chocktawhatchee River, alleged home of the elusive and endangered ivorybill woodpecker. But the bad guy is just one of their problems; they will also have to deal with wild pigs and alligators. Hiaasen weaves humor and action into his tale of environmental awareness and the need for cyber-skepticism.

    Despite its title, The Summer I Saved the World … in 65 Days by Michele Weber Hurwitz (ages 10 and up, 272 pp., Wendy Lamb Books, $16.99) is much smaller in scope: The "world" in question is that of 13-year-old Nina Ross. Heading into high school, Nina is dealing with parents preoccupied by a legal case they are handling, an older brother who's increasingly distant, and a best friend, Jorie, who is suddenly consumed with makeup and boys. Hurwitz captures the anxiety of this transitional time perfectly: "Jorie and I are in between two places. Like an intermission between the first and second acts of a play. I'm not sure how things are going to end up." Nina takes to heart what her eighth-grade history teacher said on the last day of school — "It is very often the ordinary things that go unnoticed that end up making a difference" — and decides to do one good deed for each day before freshman year. She starts by planting her neighbor's marigolds, then putting a Hershey's Kiss in each mailbox. Nosy Mrs. Millman has the logical reaction: She calls the police. But gradually, the good deeds bring the neighbors together and help Nina's family reconnect. This feel-good story about the power of simple kindness reminds us that while we may not be able to save the whole world, we can certainly make our part of it brighter.

    NONFICTION

    I Am Malala: How One Girl Stood Up for Education and Changed the World by Malala Yousafzai with Patricia McCormick (ages 10 and up, 240 pp., Little, Brown Books for Young Readers, $17). Malala Yousafzai didn't intend to change the world; she just wanted to go to school. For continuing to advocate education for girls, the young Pakistani activist was shot in the face by a Taliban gunman on Oct. 9, 2012. After she recovered, she spoke before the United Nations, and on Oct. 10 of this year she was named a co-recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize, becoming the youngest-ever Nobel Prize laureate. She has become an international symbol for education. But this book, written in her words, shows that she is also a typical girl. She likes pizza, her favorite color is pink, and she doesn't "think dark chocolate should be called chocolate at all." By revealing her relatability, "I Am Malala" makes her story even more powerful. A timeline in the back of the book outlines the history of Pakistan from its creation in 1947 as a home for Muslims.

    Carla Carlton, former Arts & Entertainment editor for The Courier-Journal, is now director of development communications at Bellarmine University in Louisville. She has two children, Harper, 15, and Clay, 12.
